One reason for the popularity of the Swiss team format is that it makes possible a dramatic and improbable finale. One occurred a week ago in the Cavendish Teams event, in which 12 strong squads including some foreign stars were involved.

With one of the nine rounds remaining to be played at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan, a foursome of Paul Marston and Steve Burgess, both from Australia, and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., and Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., seemed out of contention. After a bad start they had pulled up to fifth position.

But they crushed their opponents, scoring the maximum 30 victory points, and leapfrogged past all four front-running teams when they cut each other down. The diagramed deal, with Burgess East and Marston West, contributed to this effort.

The bidding needs explanation. One club was strong and artificial, and when South chose to show his strong diamonds rather than his weak spades, West used an artificiality: one spade showed a positive hand with hearts, an exotic transfer idea aimed at making the stronger hand the declarer in a heart contract. North crowded the auction with a leap to five diamonds, and West naturally doubled.

The same contract was reached in the replay, and in each case West cashed two heart winners. In one, a third heart was led, apparently a safe move. But it allowed South to take advantage of the good breaks. By ruffing the heart, drawing trumps and working on clubs, he had just enough entries to dummy to make use of the club suit and make his contract.
But Marston saw this danger. At the third trick he led a spade, forcing dummy to ruff. And now South was one entry short and could not make use of dummy's clubs, and his contract had to fail.
